dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, we've seen some pretty wild swings in the crypto market lately, right? Bitcoin, uh, like almost 50% up since its big crash earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, we've seen some pretty wild swings in the crypto market lately, right? Bitcoin, uh, like almost fifty percent up since its big crash earlier this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bitcoin price has lost almost 50% of its value since hitting its all-time high of nearly $65,000 per bitcoin in April.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally! And Ethereum too, bouncing back more than half after dipping below four grand. I mean, it's been a rollercoaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally! And Ethereum too, bouncing back more than half after dipping below four grand. I mean, it's been a rollercoaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, ethereum is down by more than half after climbing to over $4,000 per ether token earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A total rollercoaster. But speaking of Bitcoin, did you see that Goldman Sachs report?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A total rollercoaster. But speaking of Bitcoin, did you see that Goldman Sachs report?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the "Myspace of information" one? [chuckles] Yeah, I definitely saw that. Pretty brutal comparison, saying it has a low chance of overtaking Ethereum as a store of value.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the Myspace of information one? Yeah, I definitely saw that. Pretty brutal comparison, saying it has a low chance of overtaking Ethereum as a store of value.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, a leaked report from Wall Street giant Goldman Sachs GS +1.8% has given ethereum, the second-largest cryptocurrency with a market capitalization of around $250 billion compared to bitcoin's $660 billion, a high chance of overtaking bitcoin as a dominant store of valuecalling it the Amazon AMZN -1.4% of information.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Myspace! I mean, that's just… ouch. And they were pretty dismissive about its "real uses."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Myspace! I mean, that's just... ouch. And they were pretty dismissive about its real uses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the importance of real uses in determining the store of value, ether has a high chance of overtaking bitcoin as a dominant store of value, analysts at Goldman Sachs wrote, according to leaked sections of the report shared on Twitter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: They did. They pointed to the supposed "declining popularity" of decentralized finance, or DeFi, and said it's stagnating Bitcoin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They did. They pointed to the supposed declining popularity of decentralized finance, or D E F i, and said it's stagnating Bitcoin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The soaring popularity of so-called decentralized finance, using cryptocurrency technology to recreate traditional financial instruments such as loans and interest and designed to replace the role of banks with blockchain-based protocols, has helped ethereum surge over the last year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: See, this is where I get a bit confused, though. Because, um, a lot of the article also says that *most* DeFi apps are actually being built on Bitcoin's network. And NFTs, too, are often bought with Bitcoin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: See, this is where I get a bit confused, though. Because, um, a lot of the article also says that most D E F i apps are actually being built on Bitcoin's network. And N F T s, too, are often bought with Bitcoin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most decentralized finance (DeFi) applications are being built on the ethereum network, and most non-fungible tokens (NFTs) issued are purchased using ether.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Yeah, I noticed that contradiction myself. It's like, on one hand, they're saying it's killing Bitcoin's use cases, but then implying it's also a major player there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I noticed that contradiction myself. It's like, on one hand, they're saying it's killing Bitcoin's use cases, but then implying it's also a major player there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! So, which is it? Are these things hurting Bitcoin, or are they central to it? The article kinda goes both ways.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! So, which is it? Are these things hurting Bitcoin, or are they central to it? The article kinda goes both ways.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most decentralized finance (DeFi) applications are being built on the ethereum network, and most non-fungible tokens (NFTs) issued are purchased using ether. The greater number of transactions in ether versus bitcoin reflects this dominance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they also mentioned Bitcoin's, uh, "outdated contracts" and how it's kinda clunky for new apps.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they also mentioned Bitcoin's, uh, outdated contracts and how it's kinda clunky for new apps.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, you know, brings up the whole scalability issue. Those long-abandoned upgrades they mentioned, designed to help it *not* scale? That just sounds like a recipe for high transaction costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, you know, brings up the whole scalability issue. Those long-abandoned upgrades they mentioned, designed to help it not scale? That just sounds like a recipe for high transaction costs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, some think long-awaited upgrades to ethereum, begun at the end of last year and designed to help ethereum scale and reduce its sky-high transaction costs, could help the ether price reach never-before-seen heights.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, MyEtherWallet's CEO, Kosala Hemachandra, put it pretty bluntly. He said Bitcoin is "just a value token," and it actually *hinders* use cases built on top of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, MyEtherWallet's C E O, Kosala Hemachandra, put it pretty bluntly. He said Bitcoin is just a value token, and it actually hinders use cases built on top of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unlike bitcoin, ethereum is not just a value token, meaning it actually fuels all use cases built on top of the ETH blockchain, Kosala Hemachandra, the chief executive of MyEtherWallet, said in emailed comments... Bitcoin is simply a value token with no clear roadmap.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Okay, but then, the article ends by saying despite all this, Bitcoin is "well on its way to market dominance over Ethereum." So, how does that square with everything else?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but then, the article ends by saying despite all this, Bitcoin is well on its way to market dominance over Ethereum. So, how does that square with everything else?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even with the price plunge, long-term development is unaffected and ethereum is well on its way to market dominance over bitcoin.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? It's a bit of a head-scratcher. It feels like the article presents both sides really strongly, without fully reconciling them. Maybe it's about the long-term perceived value versus current utility.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? It's a bit of a head-scratcher. It feels like the article presents both sides really strongly, without fully reconciling them. Maybe it's about the long-term perceived value versus current utility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, essentially, a lot of people are still trying to figure out what role each of these giants will play in the future.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, essentially, a lot of people are still trying to figure out what role each of these giants will play in the future.

dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It’s far from settled, that's for sure.
